title: TEXTGAMES: Learning to Self-Play Text-Based Puzzle Games via Language Model Reasoning
author: Frederikus Hudi (NAIST), Genta Indra Winata (Capital One), Ruochen Zhang (Brown University), Alham Fikri Aji (MBZUAI), ...
background: Assessing the reasoning capabilities of large language models through text-based puzzle games that require complex problem-solving and logical reasoning.
contribution: This paper introduces TEXTGAMES as a benchmark to evaluate reasoning skills in large language models, demonstrating their proficiency and limitations in solving challenging text-based puzzles.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods focused on single-task benchmarks for evaluating reasoning in language models but lacked comprehensive multi-turn interaction frameworks.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work implements a benchmark that facilitates self-reflection through multi-turn interactions, allowing models to improve responses based on feedback.

key_innovation: The benchmark enables LLMs to engage in iterative problem-solving, refining their answers in response to feedback, which is a unique approach compared to existing tasks.
real_world_impact: By enhancing the reasoning abilities of language models, the findings could improve applications in areas like educational tools, game design, and automated reasoning systems. No immediate real-world impact.
limitations: The paper notes that LLMs struggle with difficult tasks despite showing some improvement through self-reflection.

new_terms.self-reflection: **Self-reflection** refers to the capability of language models to evaluate their previous answers and make corrections based on feedback received during interaction.
new_terms.multi-turn interaction: **Multi-turn interaction** describes the ability of a model to engage in extended exchanges, where it can receive feedback and update its responses over several iterations.

open_sourcing: The code can be accessed at https://github.com/fhudi/textgames
